Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Representations and Algorithms for Brain Connectivity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The statistical analysis of samples of images and in particular of fMRI brain images is a challenging problem, due to the high complexity of these data and their large size. Current methodology is mostly ad hoc, which limits the scope and quality of the analysis. This research addresses this situation by developing model-based statistical methodology, speci cally for the analysis of function-valued spatial stochastic processes, within a more general frame- work of object data analysis. Such data are encountered in spatio-temporal climatological studies and in resting state fMRI. The latter is used for task-free brain imaging in order to determine brain connectivity and is a main focus of this research. A key aspect is that the investigators view each brain as a sampling unit and develop statistical methods that utilize the entire sample of available brain images to infer common structures and variation in connectivity. The methods are generally applicable for the assessment of dependency structures for spatial processes. The investigators study both modeling of individual connectivity for a given realization of the spatial process, as well as connectivity at the population level. To model individuals, they investigate random covari- ance surfaces and their properties, adopting adequate metrics on the space of covariance functions. To model population connectivity, the investigators develop a decomposition for spatio-temporal covari- ance. For all proposed methods, they investigate theory, efficient computational implementations and applications to both brain and spatial data.


The investigators develop advanced statistical methods for brain imaging data. Such data are routinely collected for many individuals in functional magnetic resonance imaging and are large and complex. Their analysis requires the development of sophisticated computational and statistical tools, which is the focus of this research. The methods are then applied to quantify and compare recurring patterns of connectivity of different parts of the brain for individuals and across populations. Besides characterizing the function of the brain, patterns of connectivity may include early indicators of pathology such as early signs of dementia. The investigators also study the broader impact and applicability of the new methodology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research demonstrated the importance of statistical methods of functional data analysis for the quantification of brain connectivity, when measured from resting state fMRI BOLD signals. Quantification of brain connectivity is a difficult but important task and traditionally inter-regional connectivity between different brain regions has been emphasized, while our research shows the importance of intra-regional connectivity. Brain connectivity is a characteristic of each individual brain and reflects a current status. The new statistical methods that were developed in this project have been successfully used to analyze and discern effects of aging on brain connectivity. When quantified with the advanced statistical methods developed in the project, brain connectivity also is predictive of scores achieved by subjects in neurocognitive tests such as episodic memory and other tests. Our methods also allow to pinpoint brain regions that are especially affected by aging or are specifically related to neurocognitive status,  as we emphasize intra-regional connectivity measures. Additional results included novel approaches to model neuronal spike trains, brain networks andthe difficult but important task to infer longitudinal changes in brain structure from sparse data for individuals on relatively short time spans. Overall, the project led to 18 publications in both neuroimaging and statistics journals, in addition to numerous invited research talks at conference and universities, and a new R package for functional data analysis, fda-pace, which is in the public domain. 

In the course of this research, the investigators gave several invited multi-lecture courses at conferences, keynote and invited talks at scientific meetings and offered several courses at UC Davis, all of which were inspired by the research results from this project.  In a weekly research seminar at UC Davis, several promising PhD students were trained, of whom four graduated and two went on to academic careers at major research universities. This seminar and the courses created interest among graduate students in the statistical methodology for brain research to the extent that they decided to join our research group. They are continuing their research with promising results. So this research has helped to engage many PhD students and will have longer term effects as these students will remain engaged in the development of statistical methodology for brain research. The results and software developed also will help other researchers enter this field and thus will impact future research.
